organization.fullName: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

identificationModule.briefTitle: A Comparative Analysis of REVOLVE, LipoGrafter, and Viality in Autologous Fat Grafting During Breast Surgery
identificationModule.officialTitle: A Comparative Analysis of REVOLVE, LipoGrafter, and Viality in Autologous Fat Grafting During Breast Surgery

leadSponsor.name: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The purpose of this study is to learn whether there is a superior fat processing method in terms of graft retention in breast reconstruction after mastectomy.

armGroups.label: REVOLVE Advanced Adipose System
armGroups.description: Participants will receive the REVOLVE Advanced Adipose System technique during breast reconstruction.

armGroups.label: LipoGrafter
armGroups.description: Participants will receive the LipoGrafter technique during breast reconstruction.

armGroups.label: Viality
armGroups.description: Participants will receive the Viality technique during breast reconstruction.

interventions.name: REVOLVE Advanced Adipose System
interventions.description: The REVOLVE system is an all-in-one fat processing device that harvests, filters, actively washes, and removes strands from lipoaspirate and allows for reinjection without any additional manipulation (REVOLVE 2020).

interventions.name: LipoGrafter
interventions.description: The LipoGrafter system is designed to be a start-to-finish closed system with minimal processing of the lipoaspirate, minimizing the risk of contamination and fat cell damage (LipoGrafter 2020).

interventions.name: Viality
interventions.description: The Viality system uses the AuraClens solution that acts as a surfactant to bring impurities like blood, free oil, and cellular debris into solution, where they can be flushed out through suction.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in efficacy of fat grafting technique, as measured by 3D volumetric scanning at the surgical site
primaryOutcomes.description: 3D volumetric scanning assesses the fat graft retention defined as the ratio of fat remaining at the surgical site at 90 day follow-up to that at pre-operative baseline.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in patient satisfaction of fat grafting technique, as measured by the BREAST-Q questionnaire
primaryOutcomes.description: The BREAST-Q questionnaire is used for measuring pre- and postoperative psychosocial, physical, and sexual well-being, satisfaction with breasts, experience of care, and satisfaction with outcome. Scores range on a 0-100 scale, with higher scores indicating better outcomes.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of palpable masses from the fat grafting technique, as measured by a physical exam.
secondaryOutcomes.description: The physical exam will provide the number of palpable masses at the surgical site.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of lesions of probable fat necrosis from the fat grafting technique, as measured by a physical exam
secondaryOutcomes.description: The physical exam will provide the number of lesions of probable fat necrosis at the surgical site

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Presence of infection from the fat grafting technique, as measured by a physical exam
secondaryOutcomes.description: The physical exam will show if there is infection present at the surgical site. This is a binary "yes/no" item.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Presence seroma from the fat grafting technique, as measured by a physical exam
secondaryOutcomes.description: The physical exam will show if there is seroma present at the surgical site. This is a binary "yes/no" item.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Assessment of wound healing from the fat grafting technique, as measured by a physical exam
secondaryOutcomes.description: The physical exam will show if wound healing is normal or delayed at the surgical site. This is a binary "normal/delayed" item.

overallOfficials.name: David Otterburn, MD
overallOfficials.affiliation: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

locations.facility: New York Presbyterian - Weill Cornell Medicine
